description: Horse behavior, psychology, health monitoring, and wellness knowledge

knowledge_chunks.content: Horse behaviour reflects emotional and physical state. Early intervention prevents behavioural problems from escalating.
Body language is the primary communication method for horses. Consistent handling creates security and confidence.
Stress signs include excessive sweating, pacing, weaving, cribbing, and loss of appetite.
Natural horsemanship principles work across all riding disciplines. Ground work establishes trust and communication foundation.
Environmental factors significantly impact horse behaviour. Stress manifests differently in each individual horse.
Horses are herd animals with clear hierarchies. Dominant horses control resources and movement.
Ears, eyes, and tail position indicate mood. Pinned ears and raised tail often signal aggression or excitement.
Horses have flight response. They may spook, freeze, or bolt when frightened. Desensitization helps reduce fear.
Horses learn through repetition and association. They respond well to consistent, clear communication.
Normal vital signs: heart rate 28-44 bpm, respiration 8-16 breaths/min, temperature 99-101Â°F.
Observe horse in motion for uneven gait, head bobbing, or reluctance to move. Early detection prevents injury.
Horses need mental stimulation. Provide toys, varied terrain, and social interaction to prevent boredom.
